The First battle of Bhilsa was a conflict between Sultan Iltutmish of Delhi and King Devapala of Malwa. It was a victory for Iltutmish, who conquered Bhilsa and raided temples and shrines.
Background
The Delhi Sultanate during the 12th and 13th century was undergoing a period of expansion during strong Sultans such as Qutb ud-Din Aibak and Iltutmish. Meanwhile, the Paramaras under Devapala were under a period of defensive warfare, with mixed success.
Battle
Iltutmish raided the Paramara-controlled cities of Bhilsa and Ujjain in 1234â€“35. Iltutmish's army occupied Bhilsa, and destroyed a temple whose construction - according to Minhaj - had taken three hundred years. At Ujjain, his forces damaged the Mahakaleshwar temple and obtained rich plunder, but made little effort to annex the Paramara territory. The jyotirlinga at the site was dismantled and believed to be thrown into a nearby 'Kotiteerth Kunda' (a pond neighboring the temple) with the Jaladhari (a structure supporting the Lingam) stolen during the invasion.
Aftermath
Despite his victory over Devapala, Iltutmish could not permanently hold Bhilsa. The Adhipa he put in charge of the city and region was decisively defeated and killed, and Devapala reconquered the region.
